headings.title: What is a Servlet?
headings.content:
A Servlet is a Java class used to handle requests and responses in a web application. It's
a server-side technology that runs on a Java-enabled web server (like Apache Tomcat)
and helps build dynamic web applications.
Servlets are part of the Java EE (Jakarta EE) platform and extend the capabilities of
servers by handling HTTP requests (like form submissions, URL parameters, etc.).

headings.title: Key Features:
headings.content:
â— Runs inside a Servlet Container (e.g., Tomcat).
â— Processes HTTP requests/responses.
â— Platform-independent (Java-based).
â— Works closely with HTML/JS/CSS frontends.

summary: Servlets are Java classes that handle requests and responses in web applications, running on Java-enabled web servers like Apache Tomcat. They are part of the Java EE platform and extend server capabilities by handling HTTP requests. The servlet lifecycle includes initialization, request handling, and destruction, managed by the servlet container. Tomcat provides a runtime environment for Java servlets and can be used in standalone or embedded configurations.
